thread.title: Asian Futures Signal Pullback After Rally as Rate Cut Sinks Kiwi
thread.title_full: Asian Futures Signal Pullback After Rally as Rate Cut Sinks Kiwi - Bloomberg Business

author: Emma O'Brien
title: Asian Futures Signal Pullback After Rally as Rate Cut Sinks Kiwi
text:
Asian and U.S. index futures signaled declines as concern over the outlook for higher interest rates from the Federal Reserve snuffed out a global stock rally.
Nikkei 225 Stock Average futures indicated the Japanese gauge will fall after surging the most since 2008 last session. Contracts on the Standard & Poor’s 500 Index signaled the U.S. benchmark may extend Wednesday’s 1.4 percent retreat, which was also fueled by losses in Apple Inc. as the world’s biggest company unveiled new products. New Zealand’s dollar tumbled after the central bank cut interest rates and said the currency should fall further.
U.S. stocks failed to add to their second-biggest surge of 2015, as jobs data bolstered the case for higher rates and Apple, the largest-weighted stock on the S&P 500, slipped 1.9 percent. While a two-day advance in Chinese shares had burnished optimism in global markets, investors will be looking to data on prices due out Thursday as they continue to assess the health of Asia’s largest economy. New Zealand, which counts China as a major trading partner, has cut rates three times in three months amid slowing growth.
“Asia-Pacific shares will open under pressure today after share market sentiment reversed to negative during the U.S. session,” Michael McCarthy, chief market strategist in Sydney at CMC Markets, said in an e-mail. “Inflation data in China may shift sentiment by shedding light on growth pressures.”
Early Movers Nikkei 225 futures were bid down 1.9 percent in the Osaka pre-market, while those on the S&P 500 and the Dow Jones Industrial Average slipped 0.2 percent by 8:44 a.m. in Tokyo. The kiwi slid 2 percent, erasing its gains over the past two days, and two-year New Zealand interest-rate swaps sank 2.2 percent. Australia’s dollar tracked the kiwi lower, falling 0.7 percent as copper futures snapped a two-day surge, losing 0.5 percent. U.S. oil was steady at $44.19 a barrel after sinking 3.9 percent Wednesday.
A global stock rally that started off in Asia on Wednesday petered out during the U.S. day, with the S&P 500 erasing an early advance of as much as 1 percent to end the day down 1.4 percent. The case for a U.S. rate hike this year was strengthened by a report showing job openings in climbed to a record in July.
The Nasdaq 100 Index slumped 1.2 percent amid Apple’s declines, with the company unveiling new iPhones, a revamped TV set-top box for playing games and watching videos and a bigger iPad designed for business customers. Petroleo Brasileiro SA, Brazil’s state-controlled oil company, slumped more than 6 percent in after-hours trading in New York, as S&P cut the country’s credit rating to junk.
Futures on equity indexes across Asia signaled losses, with those on the S&P/ASX 200 Index in Sydney falling 1.6 percent, while contracts on the Kospi index in Seoul lost 0.7 percent. Hong Kong-traded shares may also be in for a down day, with futures on the Hang Seng Index declining 0.6 percent in recent trading and the Hang Seng China Enterprises Index, a gauge of mainland stocks listed in Hong Kong, down 0.7 percent.
The Shanghai Composite Index rose 2.3 percent in a second day of gains Wednesday, amid speculation regulators are continuing to direct state-backed funds to buy equities. FTSE China A50 Index futures dropped 1.8 percent in most recent trading, while the Deutsche X-trackers Harvest CSI 300 Index exchange-traded fund, the biggest U.S. ETF tracking mainland Chinese shares, slipped 3.2 percent in New York.
The kiwi sank as much as 2.2 percent versus the dollar, bringing its drop in the year to almost 20 percent. Reserve Bank of New Zealand Governor Graeme Wheeler said further monetary policy easing seems likely and that more weakness in the currency would be appropriate. The kiwi’s losses in 2015 have been fueled by a slump in prices for dairy products, the country’s biggest export earner. The S&P/NZX 50 Index was down 0.2 percent.
West Texas Intermediate crude sank as much as 4.1 percent Wednesday and Brent oil ended the session down 3.9 percent, with analysts predicting a 900,000-barrel increase in U.S. crude stockpiles in data due from the Energy Information Administration Thursday.
Copper futures on the Comex dropped to $2.4265 a pound, after surging more than 5 percent the past two trading sessions. The revival in Chinese stock gains bolstered sentiment toward industrial metals, with China the world’s biggest consumer of the commodities.
China reports on consumer and producer prices for August on Thursday, while Australia will update on employment and the jobless rate.
